*SPECIFICALLY, without 500 lines of blah, blah, blah, What is the 
IDEOLOGICAL differences between Leftism and Rightism. Not the Policy 
differences, not the "Action" differences, not the ideological difference. 
Don't tell me what you DON'T think Rightist are, Tell me what you DO think 
Rightists are. Short Descriptions, not a rambling mess of words where you 
try to HIDE what you really mean in extra words.*

What? I am supposed to tell you the ideological differences between leftism 
and rightism but not the ideological difference?

That is what you wrote: *What is the IDEOLOGICAL differences between 
Leftism and Rightism.......not the ideological difference.*

I already gave you that description multiple times. The right of the 
political spectrum includes multiple ideologies, so a rightist would be a 
person who believes in one of these ideologies. He could be a nationalist, 
he could be a fascist, he could be a conservative, or one of the many other 
ideologies that makes up the right of the political spectrum.

The main difference between the political right and the political left is 
equality. The political right accepts a social and social-economical 
inequality of the people whereas the left strives to create such equality. 
Racism, hate, the amount of government intervention, etc. can be part of 
it, but do not have to be part of it. Conservatism and progressivism are 
right, respectively left ideologies that have that concern. And even that 
is not truly correct, because progressivism actually is a philosophy 
concerned with technical and economical innovation whereas conservatism 
actually is a philosophy concerned with maintaining the status quo. 
However, just like the term liberalism, the terms of progressivism and 
conservatism are so commonly misused and misunderstood in the US that I 
added them here.

Ultimately, the amount of government intervention has actually absolutely 
nothing to do with rightism or leftism, not even remotely. If all you 
believe in is less government, then you are neither left or right. You are 
just against government intervention and that's it. But since the term is 
misused that way, you might call yourself a conservative.

That is not what I believe. That is what it is!

*You believe all Rightists are racist misogynists, who HATE anyone who 
isn't a Caucasian of EUROPEAN Descent. And all your "Facts" are based on 
this Bigoted belief.*

Never said that. What I said was that your definition of rightism is wrong 
and that actual extreme rightism fulfills such criteria. I said said that 
what you erroneously consider rightism would fulfill such criteria.

*Rightists want EVERYONE to be Successful and FREE. I don't doubt Leftists 
Want that too. The Difference is in the METHOD each thinks will achieve 
that Goal.*

Since your definition of rightism is just plain wrong, I can only answer to 
what you believe rightism to be. So tell me:

What does that "rightism" of yours do to allow everybody to be successful? 
Do you want to change how public schools are funded, so that poorer 
neighborhoods get the same chance of a quality education as richer 
neighborhoods? And how exactly would you do that?

Also, what is freedom? Do you want the freedom to shoot your neighbor if he 
works on Sundays? Or do you want the freedom to have sex with a minor? Do 
you want the freedom that you can drive through town in your tank and have 
a nuke in your backyard? What kind of freedom do you talk about?

Because that is where you are entirely wrong. Rightists and leftists do not 
have the same goals. Rightists believe that things like mandatory health 
care would impair their freedom whereas leftists would never get such a 
nonsense idea. Leftists want the freedom that comes from mandatory health 
care, so that one doesn't have to pay for somebody else's surgery with my 
tax money while he chose to use the money for vacation instead of health 
insurance. To rightists, illegal immigrants are parasites. To leftists, 
people who abuse their freedom at the cost of society are parasites, 
whether they are natives or illegal immigrants. The same applies to gun 
control. If my neighbor wants to own a gun, I want him to undergo 
sufficient training to ensure that he does not accidentally shoot my dog. I 
want the freedom to not be impaired by somebody else's freedom who cannot 
handle it responsible.

And that is the one thing where you are wrong as well. I don't believe that 
power corrupts or that people are evil. I believe that too many people are 
immature and that includes the people on the street as well as those in 
government. Both need to be controlled.

*You prefer the BIGOTED Theory of Politics where Leftists are Morally 
Superior because REGARDLESS of the RESULTS of their Govt Policies, the 
INTENT is out of LOVE for their fellow man, whereas, Rightists are 
motivated by HATE and GREED. Good Grief.*

No, because I never said that. I was talking about actual rightism, not 
that nonsense that you made up. Rightism and leftism have absolutely 
nothing to do with the amount of power given to government. That is 
determined by the degree of conservatism.

I think the confusion here is about what Jon Stewart's rally was about. I 
disagree that he said let's meet in the middle. The rally was for people 
like you and me to come above the media rhetoric and see things for what 
they are. To tell "people" to rise above the spin anybody is putting on 
stories and vote based on that. And that is precisely why the second part 
of rally was Colbert, who was "spreading fear". Colbert was representing 
"anyone" who is making you believe something by giving you lies.

Now, Bill Maher is right about what he said mainly because Republicans use 
the 'fear/scare' tactics lot more than Democrats do.﻿

Jon Stewart wasn't telling politicians how to handle things. He was talking 
to the general populous. Bill Maher was pointing out false equivalencies, 
but if you look at the original context, they don't really seem false. They 
seem like a stretch, but not wrong.

Stewart was talking about opening a dialogue between opposing points of 
view. He was saying put all the talk that people use to put up walls and 
get people fired up. His point was that Right vs. Left doesn't have to be a 
hard edge between them. It does, because that is what the media has made 
it. 

Change the public perception, change the media, make the country a better 
place. That was the point. It didn't have anything to do with what the 
politicians should do.


edit: Neither of them have to be wrong. They aren't speaking from the same 
space. I don't agree with Maher's position as you do, but he's points don't 
negate Stewart's or visa-versa.﻿

If you read Dale Carnegie's book "How to Win Friends and Influence People," 
it suggests a third option. In a nutshell, Carnegie suggests focusing on 
attacking problems, not people. The idea is to disarm and turn opponents 
into allies, rather than attack them. Discrediting or redirecting ideas, 
rather than the people that make them. I think there is something to that, 
and his book is full of examples of how that has worked well for many great 
leaders throughout history.

The challenge is how to apply these principles to public policy. I think 
doing that would allow us to be more moderate, without becoming too 
permissive of dangerous ideas and misinformation.﻿

 The maximum corporate tax rate if I remember off the top my head right is 
32% and the maximum and capital gains is 15%.  The effective corporate tax 
rate is some were in the teens but it's hard to figure out exactly where

they are paying to any given government just beat overall amount of taxes 
they paid.  This means that if they paid a higher tax rate in Germany that 
is lumped in with the disclosure even if they paid a much lower rate in the 
US.

Capital gains is only paid on the gains that were made off investment not 
the entire investment.  Real investment like say starting a new business is 
actually tax deductible so they do not pay taxes on that money to begin 
with.  To make matters worse it is a percent maximum and many these 
individuals paid much lower rates for it is even possible for them to pay

stock market actually works a deeper understanding of what is actually 
going on in our country emerges.  I will begin with stocks because most 
people see that as a positive and that a higher stock price is actually a 
good thing.  If you are business and you issue stock in that business to 
raise money for let's say expansion or even just to start it you get that 
money once and only once unless you issue new stock.  From that day forward 
you are responsible to pay out dividends to that stock.  The price of the 
stock only matters to the company when it needs to issue new stock.  The 
price of the stock is set by the perception of the company or even just the 
perception of the stock itself but is not directly tied to anything about 
the corporation.

I have a theory that the entire reason why we have boomed bust cycles is 
because of excess capital.  In truth there is only so many productive 
things that we can invest in and if you have to seek returns for your

marketplaces.  This is that we can have a record high gas prices and a 
record high oversupply of oil at the same time.  Quantitative easing is 
artificially pumping up the capital in the system in efforts to prevent a 
deflationary cycle.  Much of this money is going into commodities and other 
similar markets to including back into the debt market that they are buying 
derivatives now based on car loans and rental agreements creating an 
incentive for lenders to ignore potential risks.

Kyle, you should understand these terms. 

Theist, add far as I know, it's limited to religious belief.
Gnos/o I know is latin, for "knowledge", and is found in words like 
diagnosis.

A- is a prefix meaning no, not, without
Anti- is a prefix which means against or opposite from

Theism is the belief in a god(s) or religion
Atheism is a lack of belief
(Antitheism is opposition to the belief in religion)

Gnostic is a state of knowledge (about your belief system or lack lf one)
Agnostic is a state of uncertainty. 

One would be considered gnostic if they just don't tend to question 
something. If its not really a debate to them.

Dia- means complete. Dia/gnos/is translates to "pertaining to complete 
knowledge", but just because you have a diagnosis, doesn't mean they 
actually know *everything*. They just have enough evidence to conclude and 
assert as such. 

Any gnostic atheist would change their minds should evidence arise.
Gnostic theists might revise their world view to fit the evidence.

But agnostic theists are *all* over the place. And I consider myself a 
gnostic atheist. 
So no the two aren't inner linked. As you said, they relate to two 
completely different questions. One doesn't mean the other.﻿

funnier. He's got the stronger point here. But the two are not talking

that we do away with politics or political fighting.  He wants better 
fighting. Stewart is talking about the media and our national discourse 
generally. Our media is drawn to sound-bites, not rational analysis - it 
gives greater voices to anger and to craziness and so anger and craziness 
are rewarded. This is not helpful and it leads to bad governance. Stewart's 
right about that.﻿

You're quite right with respect to the fact that the Democrats and Obama 
have failed to find middle ground with the Republicans, on pretty much 
every policy platform, but it is a fallacy to suggest that, outside of the 
bull-pit of politics, proponents of either side of politics can't share an 
interesting debate, exchange ideas, and learn from each other - which is 
what I took from Stewart's call to arms in a bicameral debate.

Maher is correct re his comments at the administrative level but Stewart is 
correct when it comes to a discussion between the 'men in the street'. 

I enjoy lively debate with folks who disagree with my political view - 
after all, I can't learn anything from hearing my ideals parroted back to 
me by people who 100% concur with me. Maybe that's what Stewart was looking 
for - a rally of people who, don't necessarily agree with each other, to 
exchange ideas and learn from each others' points of view.

In my view, Maher is taking a blunt instrument approach in response to 
Stewart's call to arms.  I don't think either Maher or Stewart are wrong in 
their political outlook but perhaps their motivations, whilst well meaning, 
are incompatible on this specific point.﻿

rising? Why are at least 68 coal-fired power plants slated to close? Why is

acres as wilderness? Why was the East European Missile Defense Shield 
cancelled? How was Obama able to invest $90 billion in renewable energy

restrictions on embryonic stem cell research?

disintegrated and extreme polarization took over: Venezuela now, Chile
